summary: The text discusses the destruction of Jerusalem and its temple, attributing it to the sin of denying Christ. It explains that the Roman people, led by Vespasian and his son Titus, destroyed the city as a consequence of Christ's rejection. The text emphasizes that the true harm came from denying Christ, rather than his killing, suggesting that this denial led to the enduring desolation of Jerusalem. It references the prophecy about the abomination of desolation in the temple and stresses that the Jews, by denying Christ, are no longer his people.
